title: 111_hr6189
content: The "EEOICPA Amendment Act of 2010" establishes the Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act. The "EEOICPA Amendment Act of 2010" establishes the Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health (referred to as the `Board') appointed by the President within 120 days. The Board advises the Secretaries of Labor, Energy, and Health and Human Services on worker health issues. The Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health advises the Secretaries of Labor, Energy, and Health and Human Services on worker health issues. The Secretary of Health and Human Services appoints a staff to facilitate the Board's work, including reviewing and approving guidance for claims examiners and coordinating data exchanges with the Advisory Board on Radiation and Worker Health. The Secretary may accept personnel from other Federal agencies to support the Board's duties. Outside contractors and specialists can also be employed. Members of the Board are allowed travel and meal expenses while serving at the request of the President. The Secretary of Energy ensures that Board members and staff can apply for security clearances. A determination on eligibility must be made within 180 days of application. The Secretary includes security clearance budget reports annually. The Secretary of Energy includes security clearance budget reports in the annual budget justification materials submitted to Congress. Additionally, the Secretary provides relevant information to the Board and its contractors as needed for their responsibilities. The Secretary of Energy submits security clearance budget reports to Congress and provides necessary information to the Board and its contractors. Section 3686 of the Act is amended to include a response requirement within 90 days of the annual report publication by the Secretary. The Secretary must include reasons for disagreement with the Ombudsman's finding in the response, which will be published on the Department of Labor's website.
